column1: Young people are liable to think that study is laborious and uninteresting
column2: a nuisance and a bore. Nothing of that sort is true of the study of Shakespeare
column3: because for every effort there is a present reward
column4: there is no waiting to see results. Of course there are right ways and wrong ways to study
column5: just as there are right ways and wrong ways of doing anything. Sometimes teachers fail entirely to interest their classes in Shakespeare
column6: and parents say they cannot make their children like Shakespeare. None of this is the fault of the poet or of the children; the fault lies in the methods used to create an interest. If a person begins properly and proceeds as he should
column7: there will never be a lack of interest. Teachers are not needed
column8: and parents may leave their children to learn to be happy in reading by themselves
column9: if the books are prepared properly for them.
